That's Mobile Entertainment


Mobile ad network Millennial Media takes the pulse of entertainment ad spending in the space and finds that the category saw dollars grow 133 percent over the past year. One big driver of that involved ads around theatrical releases, which made up 43 percent of all entertainment campaigns on the Millennial platform. "Entertainment advertisers are turning to mobile to leverage real-world consumer behavior in their targeting... these brands can reach unique audiences that will drive ROI," said Marcus Startzel, Millennial's GM, North America. Speaking of ROI, the Mobile Marketing Association is suggesting that mobile ads should represent 7 percent, on average, of current ad budgets. (Pandora CEO Joe Kennedy cited the study in an earnings call <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001c_ksgepIhHh4OBTCunw_zhB9W57hoTFN0UwjAR_r4NzoktBsMTOWXG7BuQ3SC7pbs_LdzKxgHED57efgNP9KuIiKDWrEVqkbMOI5yygS5lHpoZDzn9_mNmgvcAUc_cKlZiHsSAzgArJxgA_evbWScfQHHZHYQM11QWlMXC8mMWaVOkgcAW-O_R-nsHZJAUpZufz-cxNpool3z0eoDht_Vw==> ). Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001c_ksgepIhHhXolq_vmEt2tXBokxYQMsMMGPfORm34utnZ3bkRpQjxMKsLmDxacUKMA-6GBeYEovLx4w2-7BIOKm51lYEBu-jHoSo3LwgnvqOMcMnAdLHSgYlp9Fjt3KakfNo1DP9AjbkXPL7mHaLglOpIybKxqHuoC-NPz6044z1KaKNtkcxf6cQlp0DdWVu92LBFR3ixvRdKEB-rfUGn3ToGlNrTT9tIJBKusqxNiX_CF7nXhHUlxabL8vdFPH7E-NxVmRvmemQuCtaKEtnbQhzvMMIYym0_fMFHLFLH3I=> .


Facebook Rev Downgrade


Some more bad news related to Facebook's ad efforts today. eMarketer now says Facebook revenues will not grow as high as expected this year, but it's overall strength is secure, as it will surpass the $5-billion mark this year for a 35.9 gain over 2011. "In 2013, revenue is expected to increase 31 percent as Facebook fully rolls out new ad products such as its ad exchange," eMarketer says. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001c_ksgepIhHiTP-Kguova4WHYNbAitiyVuQeM4l_54-KPQvqvlqHgRFGo8KaWPyziXUTRGXyCICCk_w6wqgdOXkGaGEFGM9h1IJAa7JKY3wDQJ7jN8J_ZVJT61k6qO8gythDvdrLboO-1OPRu8nENztRz_v7_pBE8> . 


Twitter Ads Gets Interesting


Twitter continues to refine its Promoted Tweets and Promoted Accounts with a new feature that lets clients target users according to sets of interests. So far, there are 350 categories of interests that marketers can choose from. In a blog post, Kevin Weil, Twitter's director of Product Management, writes, "By targeting people's topical interests, you will be able to connect with a greater number of users and deliver tailored messages to people who are more likely to engage with your Tweets." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001c_ksgepIhHjixVcQpxqgzI3wluV1JmFXfpghFAeXa6wEdg9BgexyZGC2Au1cNHun-I47FX6b2fWCJUvjVlqia0c_HNu8YWUcBPWJtJwiE9Ucu2vKFRdcaq5OW7nu5rOlHKMUszaoHJVKB6L5l-QNRh44FLZt7Jezgq0MSp6YAa3uwGAVl7fYMkjgrYvFWJGA> . In related news - Peter Kafka writes that Twitter will make $350 million in ad sales this year. Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001c_ksgepIhHgCI4oekNf00BtKl9GaLmprDvedKoTTRGDC18I2ZOM-WWgiRvOj6bq3KP1aPhC7Lgw14iHkk-s_6KompnySwbECXG1gzwv4YnMJs57IBBTY599DS3we3krKxaw4s-h5IwBAqwyrrrHz4_ouBvD6CazGZ3bwiWLPvAW80q93oJMRA1vky9C0vLzjPfLgfGj8hT5ZpMTVUw_LpdnMlgTTw8xpQklanpvEJqcScQtMJeAIrA==>  


Click & Collect


Heard of it? "Click and collect" - no, it's not an incentivized clicking scam from the early 00's. It's another way retailers are looking to overcome showrooming <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001c_ksgepIhHgnjDU_TGJskM6lIqEbNAUyDCjfSnylIAo25-ANXlWZxbxekBnCeZJaXg-aUsUKvfGCTzCa4Dl5oiJdB3yDeMGp4ulDtAZBrfZZ4URp5Xwu30YRLKNqKafrLT5B3SilaTEq6VbB2swSD9gY3BDBBG0C_IKPM4CxGXo=>  and the market share lost to digital, ecommerce competitors. From the blog: "Click and collect, or "buy online, pick up in store" has been iconic in our view, representing cross-channel efforts overall. Yet it is only one variation of anytime/anywhere choice to shoppers. Ship-to-store has different processes from picking the online purchase from store inventory, for example, and makes different requirements of the retailer." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001c_ksgepIhHiL-eAhKnMM1Ac3w-U2zimvaos546Ui6Ux8taFgvM2Gk_nKqXAJlj8zRw75lDIQdQFiB-tIK45r3ZTezpeWvzfNpuXLJyCLPhZcHWGX-5csIxCgUlqX7Xo0_pcpmjJw2tzTlkHPyH0KZ2pdu2fOf5Qit5c_umE-a9yAMpm7oKTj3WGZDKVCQtBfhSo8QxsY1V0NQ8U1w24p0gsJI8V9qFcT> . 


Mo' Acronyms


The Mobile Marketing Association (MMA) has admirably created a new acronym aimed at marketers and their troves of ad spend. According to a press release on a new study, "MXS - which stands for Mobile's X% Solution - is believed to be the first empirically based study of the rebalancing and optimization of a marketing mix to help marketers achieve a higher return on their marketing dollar investment." Translation: spend more in mobile. Read the release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001c_ksgepIhHgO8-rXciXr5_aDZ8DfdkXauUImoobZ5tPLaDH-jLROjoPJMqRP9pxS-xpGarp1glpLN8Xi_2l9sIpf2OIQBd_lDbYoCJu4lIafkZ9ARbBHKzCt40Q7BO3B3ryUHao14KJ3tRrnohdiDGMmTq_W1nmd>  And, download the study <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001c_ksgepIhHhyhNwLGlMVG_xNyYxGNwz26wlv557znyFeglVgoHN1SMyHdF5FzUWjTbY3emmxt7x-0N1hw5IArhwzPNQy2JDIFSfKY5pTwDioOpG-pR9p2bSr4fWdqg2sORSPHgtlbUk=> . 


Infographic Friday


Back-to-school audience is targeted in a new infographic from Rocket Fuel. According to the data, "Dads" is an audience hurting for recommendations. Tracking Pinterest Spend


 Amazon's Zappos has unveiled a feature in its online store that recommends purchases based on what users post on Pinterest. For Amazon and Zappos, this could pave the way for greater combinations of e-commerce and social media. "Social shopping is a total buzzword that people throw around, but I don't think any big brands have cracked it," Will Young, director of Zappos Labs, tells Bloomberg's Danielle Kucera. "When we talk to people and ask what they think is the best social-shopping experience, they say Pinterest, and it's not even a retailer." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Pvn8mpo1ZaMBD8xKHAZeVY9DdEeWuAPTBsyaRVqgE8kJzNL6hs-q1ClZja1pRn3_QfNGITeFUyrtrszfyZfZE5tFlq_vSTlxlyGAa-welJEh01EivDJYx8QaHcJB9IdSrt4w7YbHC1w4FvMsxrfJyEwrp-z59vYf7c3harMuRjCZszhUJl-mfT8tGTn8eJzGG-8OoERZNTYdVrPlYNvpAZjsaTCiHzpyyZj5gKZYFE8=> . 


Times Takes On Troll


The New York Times Co. is leading the fight against a company that seeks to charge entities sending text messages with web links to mobile phones, something that publishers had always regarded as free. The Associated Press has the story. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Pvn8mpo1ZaOUmfHjwV_D6H4VArpzBspoPYbNYOOAflu3pRZXjq-zUo8mavCmSSIT8aCtpeq-anWQaFHY2ah1-4jabn8uMWIA73cT0A7waRRZ7KFcLsoX_xaucJVc8BH3ixp0qsuO7ckpnwm_D0bJF3aR0yVfZ7mbYRyfybNKJ-nsgbXGSvFBn-E9qix-J2pcwWhUYpMf9xTYudV3dS51cM8OH-D8mzQ_n-jsXu6vpWAla_fIz2GOH4QK--0BEWbZjZIWvr0NztOHEdt0zyemHYgBR4priaebaTfQavcD2HPKNr5vXmHs49-UAAnvdCju6GF8oxoMuG7yz_7b79cZeeWQ0mqb4VMrYitNJz6Ef8k=>  "In some ways, it's a tax for being on the Internet," NYTCo counsel Kenneth Richieri said. "Millions and millions of dollars collectively is going out of the pockets of people who earned it to people who, in my opinion, didn't do anything." 


The Multi-Screen World


A study from Google's mobile ads unit shows how a user interacts differently according to the device. If you're a marketer, be ready. Google's Dai Pham goes even deeper, "It's important to understand both the sequential and simultaneous multi-screening patterns. Sequential screeners will start interacting with you on one device and then pick up where they left off on another, so making experiences seamless between devices is key. Additionally, cross-media campaigns can help you make the most of consumers' simultaneous usage across screens." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Pvn8mpo1ZaO--sQlp1ciSgwGqHqOCMLV7tObbMbUBU2xgUyqUaTTckOD6EU6-yq3fZvnzQvzNW9rB0WjZxegdp5XmOp32g0PXK04kjx0cHXLTzoLXBsoVzqIqEJ29ciTNomkmV_8TSTqbSY-sOr7V1A5NPerN-lBhIUj7YrkgdLlhyWyIQvCCDtK69pg45FFccbf3DAVSDE=>  And, get the study (PDF) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Pvn8mpo1ZaPS9tnwKIr5RcPgy4gny1WUdMe9bKgMAVqpXPA8ve3RgHNGvGOvrCKsMy5NK0r5mGmqwzQRlgBHOZJNn1SRPXO_flWIoLZuelyE17iDwvjb9NxnIZ_La3Gxk8yA25QSVq5N_UkTXR_UmlZSGz4wrPA_GG_Q3pel4H7HX_5XYSZ-zQ==> . Good data "nuggets" in the report. 


Where Are You?


Placed (AdExchanger Q <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Pvn8mpo1ZaOYXd-yEuOAnQbdrOZFWF9woGKYdwRCPMfervQCFoJ6RhOmKNdC8u-onbg_GWvVv1hN61ZNkOVf60dntkXc_Zh5ZXEvTKMBX_SAigdIIDDy1UJSuC1bC3Qa7RxkoZVAm3QYKYjNkpvjfGbYLpiUMtroHvEB9gK4wJcs2wtTVI2XnwtADSY7bq5cZN6KXldS_h1Y2q9gxiwgQQ==> &A) announced new mobile website location analytics yesterday. A press release claims, "Mobile website owners can now join application owners in utilizing Placed Analytics to understand the places people were nearby when interacting with their content. With this announcement, Placed Analytics expands the platforms it supports beyond Android and iOS to include the mobile web." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Pvn8mpo1ZaMqr6YbVkWP4HdQ1QILgg0QJrP_aSfQlyjlNdwGy49KiiTOoTKrrAsBd2WNba09lKfuJ2V33GBPHkM1r9nVdH57Zj4ji9_srHc0kiRBCQYQnOoYYlN7O230qOWCGYMnK6k=>  Razorfish-er Jeff Lanctot joined the Placed advisory board, too. 


CPM Spiral


CPMs keep falling for some traditional sites. SQAD's WebCosts Composite Index reports a 12% decline for "search engine / portals & communities" during the first half of 2012, compared to the 2011 average. WebCost director Thomas Adams tells us, "I also took a subset of the Search Engine / Portals & Communities (AOL Media Network, MSN Live/Bing and Yahoo!) to see how they, as a group, have performed and they are off 5% from the 2011 Average CPM." Press release.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Pvn8mpo1ZaNiFN9CLctlJ4A0lqZwWaN7Ez6Xnceyr7Y7Xqms8VjN-XVo6SK3KfpebWhl1BDVPKfR68DWnvnLBcWiI0CNCY8w0dH6XRdrwxhw92H3IuOEIKPHmTS800vkF8CJAay_MO5nL90p-UNB7_z_2ikKrfyArKb1Rjltu7dNkMObBMVWEN-tANVvHMOT> 


Audience Hedge


Good news, Audience Sellers! Hedge fund managers are about to become ad men. The Wall Street Journal reports, "Few ad executives expect hedge funds to approach that level of spending given the small audience firms will be targeting. Still, in an industry with big personalities and thousands of firms, some are likely to dive in." Read it (subscription). <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Pvn8mpo1ZaPARDFb7KuQ9gzxI7L0N6oMnJbfSJWvJ2SfBXFzDchQbODcTEMX-KJGtW3FXl0v2SPqekjzahMdQofzA71rpRUsup8JwyNddugQnRIfY73X58IkbeQwdjqcytzUazHNLJ0eENjqsJ9GUAN6a7aIH6bs344rXVKdMol6ZRLcSGQ1F5B4BYbBJgBx>  


Automating Marketing


Current HubSpot Chief Product Officer and former Performable CEO, David Cancel, is featured in Mass High Tech as he talks about Hubspot's new personalized marketing software. Cancel tells MHT that "10 engineers from Performable have been heading up the development of the new version of HubSpot [which] includes a rebuilt contacts database, as well as landing pages and analytics tools, and add new features in workflows, social contacts, forms and mobile." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Pvn8mpo1ZaNoKFA0SLJuW4jHpFMwDZgqm54clP-57g9dt-KNRoTcREIH7foTKrdny3Q7Meee52OxKTVYSZS8mFLsWn6Y0ptq0ZYpd0hNk1LPGf8aYX_pSq8Ra-MBbqW0o7qxOcgKKLIZTuTpDck9gZ6xy15Q55RAP4ZB0KzLP6D7tRkm7gElxiZ0YmLUI03am5WJeRHxNzfPkPTNBqfz6xbit0M6u1pm8GCDWmhibtQ=>  


Programmatic Premium


For most online advertising, the choice is one of commoditized, cheap inventory or premium expensive placements. But why can't marketers have both? Joe Krokus of SymphonyIRI, writes in iMediaConnection that perhaps they can. The idea is "programmatic premium," which Krokus describes as "With programmatic premium, consumers receive advertisements based on their location and behavioral data. Rather than arbitrary, irrelevant ads, they're served personalized ad content... Together, all of these factors equal improved response and engagement rates, not to mention the ultimate benefit -- increased ROI." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Pvn8mpo1ZaMfo3A04JZOmgBaCESD5rY7X0IfyQujrzYiY6dGSniK5J4V-z44cMNl6L4ijCbmsBOzGrhCTfAvMk2IAltLWLV1pNF8ynsUAKD2zsacvHstTkkEYAreM6xZVknI6-FoL1N8ml449xvYNQ==> .

I'm a firm believer that you need to start understanding what your first-party data assets are that you have access to, especially because they're going to be a lot more powerful in the long-run than third-party data - both in terms of scale and sustainability..." Lowering Standards


Fewer than half of all online ads are viewed for even a second, according to online ad effectiveness provider AdSafe Media. The company's study of the state of viewability suggests that only 49.9 percent of ads sold directly meet new industry standards, reports Adweek's Tim Peterson. Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001-cOnn4yd--74I0yyVC58f102Q2U8-f8cCcOXM1ia71OgGD4y0sxfqDAqMAFyA7Cnauf_sNCW57CLiN6d8C_fWz1yCuERmQ0vcbtpjp6yIhdZCFv0F73CkN3CzfAIaSYbHkfbrbr-tnqNpFyvWv6vFZPSaPPgRh_6CABolvRpRRgl4O6BWtuiGlmM9H7muvRFAJgxXu-B1yTIU-ux255XjYT1OXOJA3n7>  And, access the AdSafe report here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001-cOnn4yd--7c2FdORyKLFO7V4lC-hC0j4P8LoCfrb8Nbul-BHivPlWUeu5lnuk_XmKIkVhQXT7ObFDYWYyuyM-rwyEkb8S4YyYKJXtlgY8V1Os7Au9Xm9VLXdnMalgRgUOZkEYsIjye5_6OP-HKPPj9uAvx4GjTe5N3Bp9wsogeTnjfFeCVes34xfiwPjMXBcQ_Okm00hYnVc_GywX7NNg==> . 


Maxifying Asia


Dentsu's venture firm known as the "Dentsu Digital Fund" has taken a "strategic" stake in publisher inventory optimization platform Maxifier. A press release states, "The investment will see the Dentsu Group collaborate with Maxifier, particularly through its technology-driven digital communication subsidiary Cyber Communications, Inc. (cci), examining joint business development plans that encompass the entire Asian market." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001-cOnn4yd--5Gj9mYHm3CvHi36S8765JDTrQDMtyTo24gv_vuEpuWZhIoXbAxu0wKp3VqTfakUyG1aZfyXUFgcLo34rDTiJOFP-5WIOGSrQB7VD9XJRSGgVY1p9Sq9wTCb8rteiaSecGKrZ-SiTdG6l61iA7M01JdH6b0Ljy4moqDL7gzXICtgBpkHrZCybDHSRDiBcy-yaVUyNy55xwkO8-EQj-GaM27iJWhX91_IEhbHfYTHktFxw==> . How this works with the OpenX/Dentsu relationship <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001-cOnn4yd--4CjSqRy7Fs01PoagwXpTDaKUEF0NZPn0eW0gYGZo-2aZylnYfMqIoW5Ysibm61qbDwol0jb6BjFFCExQ-ihdmdL_ydQR1Mu5SlEE9-MXoYgUg5gbNao6zvLng0h76e2kVUo3e7BlKzhpa-xuXqWxWIf4xR7dIucusKIQqKnll_c5lSpB46EkHuX-1XcWNP-j4=>  remains to be seen. Maybe it doesn't? 


Fetch Keywords


Looks like Ebay-owned retargeter Fetchback has productized its search retargeting product and called it... FetchbackIntent. The idea here is that marketers can target consumer intent according to keywords they're searching for. This targeting data likely comes from cookies set according to search keyword referrals on publisher sites. Or maybe Ebay.com? See the product page. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001-cOnn4yd--6gz6_bWRpsH3Ew8Xyb--0RM0VKEs9ZnMFpk2FxaPa80uIJkxY2Oh_FS4yOGPWK6xU7Va-g5ODKiAaf86Y-b7RdmsH8s5ENY1Su09kXePlAkjZso4otDzls_OABYA77IZtmc6C2UdoUEGFoN8fURTFn>  The Holy Grail of search retargeting remains the user profile generated through any major search engine - umm, that would be Google. Privacy concerns remain a significant barrier here, but Big G is moving closer. 


Do Not Track, Just Worry


Digital marketers don't need to be reminded that Microsoft's "do not track" default setting in its latest Internet Explorer browser is bad news. But in case there's any uncertainty, Jeff Lerner, VP, digital media, for digital marketing firm Prime Visibility, outlines the problems. "One solution websites might try is asking visitors for permission to remarket to them - although the visitor would then have to alter her cookie settings for your site, should she agree," Lerner says, writing in ClickZ. "We could see dollars being shifted to search network campaigns, social media endeavors, or just being cut altogether." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001-cOnn4yd--5kNPoGqIwTczpl6c2cp5K_pckx9Ky3_W-59rq5lCvBIeUDfN3CrHJChzEvZtsAN2D_FnKamizcbR6P33AHLpgT1pgGDlDMRC4WhLwPxFLo374Y45bFrUljoKwvMSmUGeWhFN9eATHYiymddXDm1m3WWDQ4D3WWkebRXDp-eSgs7JM2AEiDzs8ik9pWbeAht3rhohiyslM3QLqQXLHBwJusb0jfQeLWGCk=>  


Wrong Part Of The Funnel


On Pando Daily, startup consultant Nat Kausik says that the demand generation (upper funnel) platforms of GroupOn, Yahoo and Facebook is what ails them. He writes, "We hear from each of these companies that they are improving their technology, or changing their leadership, or restructuring their organizations to unlock the huge potential of their user base. But the real problem is that Demand Generation is not a viable format for building a profitable business on the Internet, and is in secular but permanent decline." He has a solution. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001-cOnn4yd--732JT5YeWpi1CjoF0EyzwaH3wQ2yMCYh_m84wKNP1QlLLWaORowt0cMu23GewBQCMlmvCj6oxrKQkHoZIJlIh99YFGxdz1R0yvlWbOh6VbVZyPkwj6nXNR5npSQarMr127Wi1i_DwmL8HhOoc51eTY3IP7yPTnEKw2NKpZYnQtQX1JthRq-ok-yncUFwFTlDrAuDcv5B_AaYJ0taRKo74M>  


Pay-for-Performance Agencies


Mediabrands CEO Matt Seiler wants fee structures to mimic client business goals. In a Forbes video interview, he says, "Here's what's wrong with commission: I will make sure I spend every dollar of my client's money that I possibly can because I get paid based on that sum... And I'm also biased toward whatever medium has the greater commission." Odd insight: Seiler says procurement agents are among the least receptive to this idea. CMOs like it. Watch. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001-cOnn4yd--74wuvVCyoBxi5TvpNcTIpAMD310xrtARUo5GzwH_Bo4BDpLh7nNTTmnRd9ZBJzGfVj2o9CDofZ_y7mE_rR9uxcUq9SOEFySKxg_IP5cUaeXAO0jyqDjXpRmlGE8V6e5OTYzdGHNAt_-Ig6SocIbT2gVadfMk5g5Fu61K6xft1mXmg2B-1ekU44njFxWYd60vvVEzBCoAWKdOS2VQiSvGJBijPTzkuZOWDl65aQjqEY2nlwYet3VjMdulR5tGzNmDjQVfBnvsPO9h-c8zZ76xTl_CmsEtdokb4=>  


Think Big (Data), Act Local


Analyst Michael Boland contemplates the onrushing trains of big data and hyperlocal in a piece for StreetfFight. When they meet, humans and places will be imbued with demo- and psychographic attributes. "This kicks into ludicrous speed as smartphone penetration breaks the 50 percent barrier, resulting in lots more signals to play with." Innovators here are Sense Networks, PlaceIQ, Locu, Factual, JiWire, WHEREads, and Urban Mapping. Read it.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001-cOnn4yd--6QtdW79BlVWG2BAysvZSLp5wjKJzkNa3gocJ-MqM6u0vNjYq2Rx6eyVyT1XBmwK6FwZRjqNQJhNUMz0TJmMH1gXVL8Xn5c-r_nKich4oLoF79Ntk5msYjcu32_nbRcHB3a8u-tDi0iYkEHAJmd3HYitoIh9rXxrY6upVxjyqAiiMzqOi4QyFTM> 


Digital Marketing Show


In the name of "lead gen" (old) and "inbound marketing" (new), marketing software company HubSpot (AdExchanger Q <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001-cOnn4yd--4WoG3BUCotga0IAUDMMJEqQZ8hoXiJp15lxvcjyRe__imbvWU35BejTVhwbsIr_ZS6oilYcUtb1Y9nj4n6oL8gOr6AhnlexIVAYkjeHVJ7g0TJSnznDoWxOuy7BUriSTarS4ANNi6k2g==> &A) managed to bring 2,800 people to Boston for a convention <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001-cOnn4yd--6Cb1IpYv9qBj26XYIawbthegNQxvlAraqKGiXL9aZe6azOpPRB8mc3b5eVWqd_1LzL7-KCRL9yXFU4cEdDPaIDVQ75vxN81uW7CnsH6uRuZqIg3dX2LSGN>  focused on its products and related services. Boston.com reports the news. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001-cOnn4yd--5YBBhcm1d_oH6zKBJgO7N3BDpcpSBzQiI4M1JrH1Lr7ffgOhx17QDZsiPehHJmUF9W7SYdmzyRJ9WeSMlYYd2bKO8LpZFpTSfXh92woEG1Qj0GuwdBzUhUu-N_to34jpuPB-Yox21BvCdCLqX255YKGn65d1x6jUMGD3VX990-RJjqUeCBdUBQi1Tc4vlqT4Ws5-2Vu1BL-cr3KxACEcNy>  An impressive turnout and reminiscent of the 4,000 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001-cOnn4yd--4qr-1vRMGLyWjMvEODdrpmP1xrvvYzAK9PqqchuUqyyB51LkgJc2FUChGqdT_WCBJpZZFJ8pnOZs3G6t9tbaQAE0J2xeh6OmHfPPPMJQ4I_n9oRP3iTZEltNri-m4PF2hIyFyW01jF8mKjqS3a2GQ77BNYQpVv7Fw=> + at Adobe's digital conference in March. Many are looking for a digital edge. Or maybe in HubSpot's case, it's to meet Cindy Lauper <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001-cOnn4yd--5YBBhcm1d_oH6zKBJgO7N3BDpcpSBzQiI4M1JrH1Lr7ffgOhx17QDZsiPehHJmUF9W7SYdmzyRJ9WeSMlYYd2bKO8LpZFpTSfXh92woEG1Qj0GuwdBzUhUu-N_to34jpuPB-Yox21BvCdCLqX255YKGn65d1x6jUMGD3VX990-RJjqUeCBdUBQi1Tc4vlqT4Ws5-2Vu1BL-cr3KxACEcNy> ?

Patents And Display


Aol has announced that its investors will receive proceeds of its patent sale in the form of a stock buyback and dividend. See the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001AmRV6w9ExZ07kQ6Dp6AGYs99X2gsKFsaPfRifll0Ohrsyz1IE7jijzuz6q1KyFh3XTXLS8MjAJ4PJBOb3gwRPP1OATcP9ckUULAJc7_QqIZ8lBVcZi5ABypRMa42YG4eenDoRR7AEfYTAkngFCjp_8CpGlPdkzwe6p2eMMMK7U8H5JuTV8fLpXJGKaEHTz289u2XGyZp9QW7ROfnlvj5283LGb6wRL4XtsQO44v4OAg=> . Analyst Ronald Josey of ThinkEquity was positive about the development in a note to investors but added, "To be more constructive on [Aol] shares long-term, we need to see domestic display growth that suggests AOL can at least begin to maintain its share of the domestic display market, which we believe is under 5% today, and falling. Devil ads at scale, video, and Patch should help here, but it remains relatively early." 


The Mobile Rocket


In the history of humankind, nobody and I mean NOBODY, has seen anything like it. According to mobile ad and analytics platform Flurry, "Compared to recent technologies, smart device adoption is being adopted 10X faster than that of the 80s PC revolution, 2X faster than that of 90s Internet Boom and 3X faster than that of recent social network adoption." Read about the rocket. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001AmRV6w9ExZ2Y4GEfiLEXicXknEnBLK2IUcvGJ_5e0bAnsBJRrNAAZodEcEAfiJNRRXwOfbHnFWxXi-TqvEBm9krrO_crBsE6-ZaPA2nnKuJr4QWQ1wHTSrJBNbdwD4R-mRLa_A-gUV-VVXjmY3JQtJj4VS5A9CYzVbpNMBcGl2ubcm78LIpG-5GmyIhrfMNA3M96tcuqmwk=>  


Agencies + Tech = Harmony


Marketer Judy Shapiro says that engineers and ad/marketing people all need each other. In Ad Age she delivers the koom-bye-yah meh-lord: "The flood of platforms with their vague opt-in classifications has undermined the overall trust consumers place in opt-in behaviors. As consumers get a flood of unwelcome opt-in outreach, they increasingly opt out, poisoning the opt-in well for all marketers. It's useful to remember there's big data and then there's bad big data. Platforms obscure one from the other." Agencies and tech unite. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001AmRV6w9ExZ0vtf-_h_0TibvUJLZMSWxIO6RNpBkBoX1HlYeO5YXkIsLOfaatmc-gBej3gFkADP1-hU3XXtOwsi6rYjMIoquNg3fYu_8-bXk4B1o_kRGnE1FxczlutQcrLy6qj13VSrYvz5JZeZwoyMhC62XA34vW2OLt9liMlS7lL7XNA3Pa5Sg1_faNmBXB>  


Adding FB Revenue


Robert Peck <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001AmRV6w9ExZ15zgiWqa43LHWvDYsxj56NaKjkxUhO3i9laLVzaVkq8Ksn9Tet0hXuB40EQIQKQFNKPXgaZDma1CwG3KASFqZYLTo2WcxVL5jhf_zXLAClpP64rL27zC2ttiGXsWrhomvH1QdAp7uaX89ibPhuwF9ehonYZPx8XJU=> , a financial consultant writing in Business Insider, has some advice for Facebook and suggests several ways it could get a $7 Billion with a capital "B" revenue boost: "Based on the ~500m users that live on Facebook and the ~1.6b searches done each month... Facebook could generate ~$1b of incremental revenue immediately... with some tweaks, it could balloon towards $3b of revenues per year. The best part, it would be almost 100% pure margin (just like it is for AOL today)." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001AmRV6w9ExZ1bnR69IOIEjqG_baG0lu9EDcTpGJTcODeGF462mm2BVeUwPLwPlXKKF-ywZvKjPm4-i33W1rPxcWkQWuct0RqSWXvK-L4HUng37L0SVfh-nONzeaOcllWxMhwCVV6NVrKcpJMjkQBN4ZHZwJ1Vh90mJZQYkii50ueqJjEeVq3wVmivmNHFG87n>  


GRP Religion


Facebook is pushing for standardized reach/frequency metrics that will help it find a natural home in every brand's marketing mix. Brent Smallwood tells AdAge's Cotton Delo, "The ultimate vision is for a media buyer to purchase, for example, 100 GRPs on TV and the equivalent of 50 GRPs on Facebook, which together might generate the equivalent of another 20 GRPs through owned and earned media on Facebook. The buyer would then have the understanding that all together he got 170 GRPs." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001AmRV6w9ExZ2h_Cot4faiHUAm_g3pLRa_36eW0AQdo79JhbCovZp7l1zBB0X8wjx5r2RXxruqUpY3qMJKCY46HWPMeQNRFLdkqwGtUY5cELJTmm4dSikpEDj9ouE2q1fJk-vwbocabSN8LdQwJhWPSYaSVduy_OqPf4RHUa6BYWDA4zx4jeLNfolJCp_RqQGbY_4Red_vw9F0Mtc6yYUzCA==>  


Monetizing Bollywood


Indian streaming music service Dhingana has launched its ad platform and nabbed Facebook ad product chief Gokul Rajaram as an advisor (catch him at AdExchanger's Human Centered Automation conference <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001AmRV6w9ExZ38zvgOjehQqc1GJilEWXcY3Y8yOQvJodOh-y0yic_HndCPY9RrV5ucgXwQnJC1fEdMQxzMP9vKuD1oISY9Vzv4sMcl-o2fkegW8BUpuNzmyFZfigSKYoHeoO4stCIYKpc=>  next month). Anthony Ha reports for TechCrunch, "Eventually, Shinde says advertising should make up 70 to 80 percent of Dhingana's revenue, with the rest coming from subscription services." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001AmRV6w9ExZ2s88gCkiEr9YN7EDOfLTmu3bGs17fmUGItP6D-fTbnngqwUTkKg_fQP6bzEjTK7dcZbqpSHn_vDnWgX4lM1i2V_Wq9oON9VE3sMkxc436vrgJblfZtHtmOAvfOI-P9XGDgo5zuFNfN-st_OBEXHpZufddTsHuvEeI=>  Dhingana isn't just about Bollywood hits, but also new and traditional music. 


Three Screen Heaven


AT&T Adworks is rolling out a new platform to help advertisers put mobile and TV data to work for their online ad buys. Mediapost's Laurie Sullivan reports, "The AdWorks division worked with AT&T Labs to develop an algorithm that allows brands to target audiences based on aggregate demographic data from TV programs watched or downloaded on apps, games and videos on mobile." Read it.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001AmRV6w9ExZ360zjPvXLe93u70JEnVSvB71spXMPuWtQdPw6pomBlKXOTLRF6o_g08_SyIl0qA-ul05hBRxzbxko7Tg3CH6dpneloidSk3dgAKrKRWCorcmWFwNzF7Kt5VJwpiTeP456r39Q3D2FRvRDIWFYStTIhEbfRdk-a7ufAKjWa2a7sl9y9ttbrLCC48ZwxwjT4lLLZ1V5N6OhzoPnhVz5wk1S9fAsl1i0NoWo=> 


Mobile Ad Exchange


OpenX says that it has launched a mobile, private ad exchange in Japan for CyberWing Corporation, "one of Japan's leading media representative companies and a subsidiary of NEC BIGLOBE," according to the OpenX blog <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001AmRV6w9ExZ3p23pt4MxzNTg0vlEI53gcmq1lYQrlk94wa4h1omV2J-7VMnbZChXNrE3a2FKxFaV9khDtKQsaM3or4vVeym7TO2x4upUDh7-TIICtxsYavbEFKd5XNYwwCJWtVRgXoyDNw3pTiXgLiz_tww7MpPukLmeTC7ispSABr-O2-wW34iRixWA7XoTzsPgh-XgoRjk=> . Director of publisher solutions, Ari Oberman, says, "Although we are still in the early days for both mobile and Real-Time Bidding generally, Japan is leading the world in mobile monetization in many ways." Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001AmRV6w9ExZ2vEMhMbJXiK2R9Eq_Y6QnqoVxW9a3l0bz6UIwRUAxC4H1qZUTJHSoPqB2ItI0GP2kqPrywZPfgPabLgtfHMyyOBjmCB4KQ8Lv2wfHuLuvEOVUZtLT_y8ueSuwAVu3bdHtjOpknFgaq9VCXiIEVY74zv7wbyeL1sgLbva7wUrAQIkaXvnDV84uRiNeJoLCjR00=> , too. 


Too Many Ads


And you thought too many ads on a page was a digital-only problem? It's been around since, well, TV. Read this WSJ article about Viacom adding tons of TV ads to its programming: "According to data from TV-research firm Nielsen, [Viacom]'s Nickelodeon and Comedy Central networks boosted the amount of ad time they aired in the first half of 2012 by 9% from a year earlier, to a combined 1,901 hours. That followed a 7% rise in all of 2011 and a 4% rise in 2010, Nielsen found." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001AmRV6w9ExZ0iIOBGTbE6DVjxWtxfV5JlUffa2c9IDEpBGn3Y--I3OxHqxd2vO6mP6YKD7YPJ1ax4FpUpxAeMpcB97C0kU12CvjrswGi-zLITWOihiinBLiS6hcGe3GzjIfOHkZHfxGbllXqqbZp8VL7Njt-pFozBFITmVuez-_X_LJ9bLbxdN44rBbKk1Mio>

RTB'ing The Background


Everything will be biddable. Perhaps Gourmet Ads, which has been "busy" with its real-time bidding strategy, is proof. The vertical ad network has introduced real-time bidding of its background skins through its private exchange enabled by AppNexus. Read the blog post <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XpmsXrdPdkKJRhvBIcvKk7IyE6UlYKP5RY6npXU3EQF5w8At2Au3aIf1bPfDCktvDgYhqGPqsuCCseN57TeRtYONZsOEA4HpRA4JLa2J-qAu3wQcYB6rGUv8ygCIfBo1pJPCRYLIeRZXh1CXtDT3-p3IJZSFC8Je> . Also, in addressing potential buyers such as agency trading desks, demand-side platforms and the like, the company provides  a template for differentiation which many publishers might want to use: "Buy on Brand Safe Inventory (Our content only features cooking and recipe websites); Inventory Includes Above the Fold Impressions; Market Rate Floor Prices with no minimum spend; (...) Ad Sizes include 300×250, 160×600, 728×90." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XpmsXrdPdkKCSrZOSahFretR2L5JdEJXNr-UOail7msKGkqTAHGnLaaIQygdtEjP_aDpn57dgBD5rCCCXM7vs3bwRy71zzsSuMAoMSZ1IqkhxTTbgGfAU-KhAiNcJopmrfxqi1zPuuA=> 


Audience Patent


Former Yahoo! exec and current Inadco exec Dave Zinman announces on his personal blog, "I'm a proud papa and need to share that the United States Patent and Trademark Office just issued Patent # 8,234,166. Thanks go to Bob Filice, my co-inventor, who in point of fact did most of the work to file this patent, and to Yahoo!, for believing in this enough to invest the legal cycles necessary to get this across the finish line. For their efforts, they now own the patent for 'Automated user segment selection for delivery of online advertisements'!" Read a bit more. And, see the patent on the USPTO website <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XpmsXrdPdkKS017KPZ7ExwhcjpcIaqkmU0aQ0adWLrUHpWV-tCZvhGuxd1zASDQwfcKdxbBqjZ-jV7NYecuBLOdT3eyixKij2qYYaZZXgiHx9Z2yBYmG_g30SQcCk6iSU1AKyE8RVOpU-lDKjzrjJ3Zx-uyZQ1CALhzL-hYWoY5i63b4Hhy9VVFbNKqcMhqwxPBRI8khiMmcwC6ZNUSWMU4cAI5wt4RY4ab9EWErP2uLhKWw7iy4z4jWr9eWNUxzvReoQjApmnG3v3F2P_cMjqH3_JKPso2FxYHapD1WX6HwI4SVY3knEmU6ppWIZdTmYa_2nN8SvK0s1m0_sDxSiJBzA1X1e_RbwLRs8Pc6JmFTtxS8749Q5sCO9nUAxQO6MUAiDG36_EH37-lsb3r_Sw==> . There are no patent attorneys at AdExchanger, but after reviewing the "abstract," and like many patents related to ad tech, this patent looks like it could affect all the audience targeting tech companies in the ad ecosystem if it was enforced. 


More Patent Play


On Friday, Apple won its patent liability lawsuit against Samsung and was awarded, initially, $1 billion by a California jury But, the final result is still a long ways off as judicial reviews and appeals begin to pop up. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XpmsXrdPdkKs__VH7lEB9vXgiv1-4qgtCFKCqXXLSEXfsQLU5Ag48S6rZMLdLgJ0n2LFdFIU5ASJZPaFndeuyoJPaLGMU-3RX8KgpSYcNlToGOS5yTSw8UJwRmp9w6LnhdBN7EVZAOv4AMZyXUi384fOSb9uZm-XejAQ3uFAl8IIjjghefZM2ua008rx0PTVjj-BRuCUGxE=>  U.C. Berkeley professor Robert Merges observes in the NY Times, "It's not good news for Google. Apple's real target is the Android ecosystem, the Android world, everything having to do with Androids. That's really what they are targeting here." Read Bloomberg News summary, too. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XpmsXrdPdkLavguYR6Kb3BPBnOPkEY-QP6Km1VE957gof5sePd0KKD505N1ogRlI-BxHelaT2vZFbI63kTVOkPhVecyv_UkubDtpQzO_p-abYjEHOkpODGypPcjZiMkh-OZu3MOMZY5gt5YIXIl9ib-47AncrL7EvBZMLOLFrw4DgdfXicWq9E0L7R_-TeJHC8BwaKeuCuH0ZiYCLq_iT5b8bIqJvABO>  


About.com Bought By IAC


A NY Times Company press release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XpmsXrdPdkLkqi-IKP5WxTDgob7d76gE6XCIiiqeG_wzWgOv33jpgI6rLvwXX9UHBFP9FKwD3Pu2nSdPX_YW9SaohoR98sIlZPO3xw1UHE8hmEWeToxR0p9HuytvoxV-L98YYsqZ7B-fkp8opFOfsBBpl09EwZ6In9zZV48CoEutoV79B9W5BOb8y1qRcA80vc7ZdfXyq_BOgO-FVrSPUMyh2S_1KXC1>  made it official Sunday: "The New York Times Company has entered into an agreement to sell its About Group, which includes the Web sites of About.com, ConsumerSearch.com and CalorieCount.com, to IAC for $300 million in cash. The all cash transaction is expected to close in the next several weeks. The Company intends to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes." Read more on the NY Times Media Decoder blog <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XpmsXrdPdkLTS18ZgoWFI9BqOvmUWr9qsHaPO-q5aLpS7qjHF1tEwWhPiEkpRMoHHVbsfXBUBnEoib9jOHVVYJX6b0W2KAIBygEPqFZxXKg1pAGDR516UALx4VvveqXtmqjbSyQGbNXUPULKl8L55NSaKx3CAh9WaFPhn-A3A_62C-ZWaD_NQsUUa1eoYsdjCCp2ipA5kLp2jue9bOwiBJjmB8pnb6Ei8J99PogyhV4=> . In the end, there was no Answers for About.com <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XpmsXrdPdkKl8IQONCFDoYH2rbEw0vyFTdqlb3UWOXGdyKIlzRRpEmmj6Oyus8IwDv_EDsiPs7ZFDJzDynAIBYHeLVLhkYV3QHq2BrvwNCi9bWsUnzIAZ71stAwVdSD7zZGcf7TCn-I_98YRfFeOqlLmm4KC0jln> . [rim shot]


Planning Display


Why not call a spade, a spade? Or a display, a display? That's what Google appears to be doing as DoubleClick Ad Planner, which aggregates display ad audience data across Google's display ad network, will henceforth (Sept. 5) be known as the "Google Display Network Ad Planner." Google is continuing to align its products. Product manager Vincent Lacey says in announcing the change on the Inside AdWords blog, "In order to maintain the highest level of quality planning data and to invest in new functionality, we will also need to discontinue some existing features. You will start to see, for example, that certain filters and demographic data will no longer be available in Ad Planner." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XpmsXrdPdkKw5mcLBgQCHPzw6daof8rj8ck0pccZnrTC-Sz8_paf16yiYyTz728HPT6du7osaAClRLfGpbZNd6dLVzk1ROtoFmOoVqwNkRtMpmcwPBtPjxGYrjklruPDJYu7qaCY9aXLJu_3C-TfgAJFsn_-lOcQtlYcB-XpCw52nED_D_mspsZqUiFhMtzj>  


The Running of the FBX


TechCrunch's John Constine echoes  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XpmsXrdPdkLFhjhM-oaECo21bn5clSG8HYg7N7dz7WNuM_h7VT9N-Lb8U0H92RZbSxG8aXY-PMs7OyDh4uNs8b9QxhnGUg6F-eqz11dbiNtz21mcHfg0GLvRmcuv6Zf5BLmbvlroT6hd6JvSbOalnkSLXEeAeSwYuvwiSasfnuF7o15Qle8XgjHXeboWW1KRuKVk5jO8NuATLkNtKXEr96fjWdlvEyPL8vcULHTCDdk=> the AdExchanger article from 8/16, which confirmed the Facebook Exchange partner increase to 14 total partners (DSPs buying Facebook display). Constine says that retargeted ads are running and "one source close to Exchange tells me 'initial results are good, they're going very, very well.'" Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XpmsXrdPdkIjMiNrITXsWwIOn6QzD9Cj-PM9ILYGboO-wA_DbrzO1-xsHkEaUsi64AdZAeOzRHQIc0_qaeb3BOnMwv8aoJyCCm_klDgn4ZiWyXt4po1VCgi96hQne_9n70g4XBBEvD293XQ-gL3xuM9KhUbIWnpn0d3GsnZnkcd9eDGjCfCvYA==> . 

In fact, you can test this for yourself, go to our Yahoo retargeter story from June <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XpmsXrdPdkJogMwIWjfeMRV44wjzD7KnX6mkl6OgNASiRqkaGSjm3CWdC0e25TSPk9ZJ8iHeSehN88vuPzs8HsmKflGVVyLaB6V4G2pDGJHbNi2XAi0tpIeAURm6aPNlw_OqM0Xgdjjy8rKJliNYhAKBQjatLdtOuEtKhsuCGksIftVWoMo0mIDACaCENKFG> . TellApart is a Facebook Exchange partner, so click TellApart's Online Shoes screenshot to scoop up a cookie. Ok, now go to Facebook. Wait a minute or two, say the words "there's no business like the retargeting business," refresh your Facebook timeline and you should see an OnlineShoes ad in the right column.


Ad Network Conspiracy


Stéphane Pere, VP at Ideas People Media, part of Economist Group, takes ad networks to task in a Digiday think piece titled, "The Ad Network Transparency Conspiracy." He writes, "Another common misleading practice looks like this: An ad network sells an audience to an agency at a $9 CPM. The network then buys a very small portion of the inventory on premium publications at $40 CPM and a large portion of the inventory on the long tail at $2 CPM. The real eCPM of the campaign for the ad network is then $2.50, and the context is far from the agency's idea of premium. Yet the marketers receive a collection of golden screenshots, showing ads on relevant publisher sites, implying their campaign hit the target audience and editorial context." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XpmsXrdPdkLHaZEjiWj9tigZFUHlzPSLWY2CpEO_tXT3DRJA_R_-DEfK8cp0snU3tr60_3yMv7WehLd_2GkVTeRx5VI7o05kKVoSdJGIOPAxmBCZ_WtfUQHD7klT_ySw_scdeWbIXo44nXtoFPOkl_7ImgB6D-S2BXs6LnWIJYq1hHdArxW0QA==> . 


Google, The Content Co.


On Marketing Land, Danny Sullivan examines the transformation of Google to a content company. He writes, "How did we get from Google being a search engine that pointed to things, like travel guides or gift cards sold by other companies, to being a content company? It's a position that more than ever before makes it hard for Google to assure other companies that it won't play favorites with its search listings." Read this argument. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XpmsXrdPdkIpMs5XsVW0jU0D2R9LeyXHW4MyDygERGbEN8kmqQAZhdtnMSB9gEp-KsM4E4OXc69_Q8PXk2jzGnaDjG3n7E4dUKeeiUpgmLT0pm4WtBHYSJpgyEhqZeS_koez0MtdeyVBU-mnhxl4RZqDhlbqjqb-WwNEBBqMzbLMZUQIimxjqqwFo27bYRsvZwsx647VRxE=>

BrightRoll Teams With Datalogix


More babysteps for connected TV as a deal was announced yesterday between BrightRoll and Datalogix, which is using TiVo viewing data from 4.2 million U.S. household set-top box devices for its DLX platform. The release states, "With DLX (Datalogix) TV integrated into the BrightRoll network as well as its exchange, advertisers can extend the reach of TV campaigns to viewers who have not seen specific ads and expand messaging frequency to target audiences effectively aligning TV and digital media plans." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g8IDHTJDf486J-xZMNzZhyRhUwDdgTur5mWrTW5UVcw6pzXyrTD3BUaCdEZMyok8N6fa_A49d3VBPyqo6SK7Li1IH48iePR0NSETwQAmDVRwJvvzmj0Ic624dgaX_gIPi5kwbGZBMqRIDnp7RPcwqshTfIL2sbRtseoivgDuN-uXvbNtJFhvrzvGyciU0eAKxVk7b9gqqnJQxixpKtfUSiCQk6vILtI6olDr7pCWxZBp8Bc6nmd4KhX2_w1N0A8EVejwMRZLZIM=> . 


FB Ad Strategy


Facebook opens the kimono to parts of its "mobile first" advertising platform for a New York Times article. The NYT's Bruce Chen speaks to a number of FB execs including Gokul Rajaram, product director of ads at Facebook, who says Facebook's "strategy would mostly focus on so-called sponsored stories, which treat posts from users as ads <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g8IDHTJDf4-txrmUvwf9LjefZYZ-l6xI7btlNzC4UKoe6UhjDY6b_UTtcZbFET_Z0otIBA1xf6Qxfl3o_GieE6OcxS9M9I35js6JaU933hBm8DuHERA6Tz6soOZyzArYmd06FMjtEaS8BA7zIZZAITqgEr3oEurmCuSKOWyV4U4fhbSL5aSRxb1jda6cQ1ho1ob25rIGxV-KmOYWvwlz4JbUFtGm4ZBm> , amplifying word of mouth. (...) Facebook started using sponsored stories in February, and they now generate about $1 million of revenue a day, about half of which comes from mobile users." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g8IDHTJDf49jZQK1m5rWBklLnoi38ePnEVXJhDup-JSTJAYaWpr6OaFfJmPby30EDhH7I236jkwcvmrZH21hW46hZcocKXtjdj-gOmFVj4_qlMiB2lWUEwfC1D2Mf-iSo-JQS4J5RgDLUp8uiaSJhnFmA2UvX-0CkL43ysqKBZd6_n-Xo-5_EIYhaN2pMI0TU90qsqtIqfAdgBnaS-MdvH-fU1JEo2I8> . Rajaram will speak at AdExchanger's Human Centered Automation <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g8IDHTJDf48WBEPOJRbz7q4TWDY5Na2iZfFem1I1dSDLzIJMgXkUmDJFtbq4Ao4_VRfpLmceVhbGSK66Jt_Rl9gcjTMyyl--sKwp2qTNnE6yLqz-67W_vQK0HgLf8x27zks3BOSgilg=>  conference on Sept. 20. 


Budget For Banners


On Ad Age, Allen Wang, CEO of China-based parenting site Babytree, says marketers like Heinz and Procter & Gamble are looking for something more sophisticated online offerings to reach moms in that country: "Advertisers don't want to just give you a budget for banners. Specifically we've noticed three areas where they want more help. They want to send their content to their target audience. They also want to find a specific group of influencers or opinion leaders for their brand. And send products to the women making decisions." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g8IDHTJDf4-gIFYqYW7vIRMtu_zCd0jn4P8TsuIKrlvrD_b1zoYMdjpJLOthXZR7n8iCYTadqN2FDwvWd8-0g6iDglOUwg-SVOo_85uhqA0EE7HM0WisAqUM7_D9IX7UJrJ3NCKsdfQxbKE4TTm_KoYlGc33jZ3nSRVM8rZabNDnCXXy5ShqhYkKQ3wwrtwjbTYD7ivryWs=>  


Miller Time Over


News Corp. has confirmed that Jon Miller, its chief digital officer, is leaving the company. AllThingsD's Kara Swisher broke the news and speculates that the departure may be related to News Corp.'s plan to formally split the company into two pieces. She prognosticates about Miller's future: "Clearly, this is a world Miller will return to easily and it's likely he'll be starting something sooner than later. (Maybe bringing the band back together with [former Fuse Capital partner and ex-Yahoo executive Ross] Levinsohn?)" Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g8IDHTJDf4_2r5iaCc5q9UsGNuCOtxxi_RfgTTCqNckYrnsLLpd-UNALyBlq6_BH6omHRRSL8Ina8bFzHt-MG3HGd8Kw6rRLJ2eM6Zoqgjn2cE2K_dgw8kI22aK7BNnDRjh-TzU-EhMOkIvWx1vpxMAF4ZUkOCfpyu32T0d80TnLIrPVYM9XEUh0iEqLMvrF-vOV68jmIqE=> . 


The Top 50


In a press release, comScore EVP of sales Jeff Hackett reviews the top 50 web properties in the U.S. according to comScore data. The indefatigable Hackett notes the season's leisurely pace: "With summertime leisure also in full effect, many others took a more laid back approach to their web browsing by visiting community-based interest sites, including Pets and Beauty/Fashion/Style sites." Download <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g8IDHTJDf4_JBnvlM-jE1Jg1AVWaAwcR4aTmmRFJLZas_9T8X7TYCb45XYGm6TVU38iTX67Fm8C6gXytTqi8MLcxJCi7LsubDyZxosv73TgDekxokJCit0tWMe5Crnaw9VMGIvnTa1vewWMLydOAOkdLEezR7gcc1RnaORki0Gs7kU_D27PKfiidm384liKuAOBG6AExGFo-5puMMVtI53PAlEi_73gDLaYc-V1ZK_rY9Epg4fU3ZpWhiLd9hJTSehOAFfBh_PpmbDLX-lWcXMw16Og7wcZxEQdjb2nyPoFkZecJv2qXJsWlC8_CVaDbP_ch0AF3kkg=>  July's PDF as you enjoy another gimlet. Also of note, SSP Rubicon Project continues to pay the piper and remains cordoned off in a category known as "Top DSP/SSP/Ad Exchange Entities." comScore promises - as it did last month (PDF <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g8IDHTJDf4-645EtFEM1_DDeHpjbQEKmdF8WY2zc6KiaAXxJQdNO0xPXzuNaa0Trsu6AZ6Yw17GY3wSTyCXKZ-8EHL8h9YBkGjHw-cECKju_4rkBN67F9MFxw8y-SkzBWrWjz52bgA0QyEsnrHVw5TxG2iUjc1_PLOVY_KlWCnDcZ9FSGTKyzg1orhDGJIhAv87IB3pkNjx0nRAM1KbKGqD267ObMLbfhj1GtqYPzLpE7uQul-uZNcOYx1NDruZyEZPJ2C3jbsa1yN69-B6jPBB0PFl3SRhAJkVPXLiUNyXGmv0KeKLAYnkGsCGwclq4Ck-XMr8hETw=> ) - that there will be more "entities" in this category in the future. Sounds mysterious.


Now Playing: In-Image Ads


On ClickZ, GumGum says that it delivered more than 1.4 million ad impressions and a click-through rate of 0.43 percent for in-image ads promoting the film Cosmopolis. Clickz's Mary Lisbeth D'Amico reports that even though in-text ads are sometimes seen as annoying as gnats buzzing around your head, in-image offers subtler attractions. "We don't get any hate mail," claims GumGum CEO Ophir Tanz. "We believe the ad should be in line with the text and relevant to the context. It's less of a sledgehammer and more of a targeted message." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g8IDHTJDf4_tRFRz_Bcp3xNqlCVgqXAtN1szIR_AKdn4QalrjhBRbORBkt-MDbQUf1yi1AtAVo7I4Ru0-iFIrjvZuC9NSFbFFirRp2tTi5X43_hce75DwYqadsO3V0NmCMzt9DpwtkVRk_HDo2K08tYtZFfAbzN5yDs3AqT_yaerWgPPuRSsjmqeubiczLwzpj3CqZw6rLbkyHf1t8GqUQ==>  


Big Ads!


On its blog, Microsoft Advertising shares performance results of the IAB Rising Stars (big ads!) ad unit it developed - The Filmstrip. Take the Alfa Romeo ad unit for a test drive: "60% of users who interacted with the ad watched the video on the fifth panel right to the end; 9% of unique users who watched the video then clicked through to the Giulietta microsite; Seven minute average ad exposure, 500% longer than the average rich media execution on MSN Homepage for PC." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g8IDHTJDf4916If9VedCN684Tprc0br6x74Z2EfqfnYGgLwzF4mk0Z3ta0xWYobqMwY9ntNAQJip6KpWMAUBlmt_oaYhA939vihDJBxAncql8O-3LYJpKueVPcTDJ03wMJx5fK-PxSzW9fQYFXxKkzV2NPlqlBw9ljKo4MHUKo9CuhrIc-kU6Qcx7rxgvIEwjcJiwy_8hGfZk6qLiy1jERG8WgONDFkLDPJ-Zm6DA0-UhAWfw_DF2wjDG4tpOXPEKBZaKaifLS_Za1bNTAA9v5XVMen8c-F-S1nNxZ0es7pmX5MssQiyiXY3FHN_KC03tLRryCjCDQKteYGgRU9lOw==>

Sponsoring Search Ads


Facebook is adding search ads to its product mix reports Techcrunch's Josh Constine. But don't expect too much from Facebook's emulation of the Google's model says Constine, "While these will 'help' people discover new apps and content, I don't see Sponsored Results as a big improvement to the user experience. Then again, they're confined to search typeahead, so I see them as much more benign and in-line with Facebook's business philosophy than the new non-social news feed ads for app developers and Page owners. Those could dilute the feed's quality, which is core to Facebook's value to users." Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w8tQbudJtq8P2pqdKHyfxDbELZgIwRjBhBjPmliojG902dwy_m9pu9JqCota5Q4dnucPR1xUly37VFvF92C3cCqlh6bjyMqHCSEEc-4FzIB3PTFjb4fs5tsxT7_QZ4GaPkQy4GpQnuMBC4HVin5NnovI4OfKGqJv> . 


Big Data, Little Revenue


- that's the way C-suite executives sees the ad tech space, according to an Oracle survey from earlier this year now being revisited by eMarketer. 43 percent said they were still at a loss to turn consumer data insights into anything actionable. "Retailer executives, too, expect their biggest Big Data challenge to be using the flood of information to improve the multi- and cross-channel experiences of customers," eMarketer notes. "But they also saw significant challenges in a range of other areas, including supply chain and inventory optimization, and using customer data to tailor product offers and other campaigns." Suck it up. And, read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w8tQbudJtq-pYUVTTP-3nQgpP2tmDw9yNBGLbl5rJHps9teFhPuMUt1ENuUEU2m36ApBbOh6JwGnI8686Nojo_BPxKL4iUb_T66xIh95qr7ihR7aBfghzyG2npg4i9GPHHJEJ1sEl-1DljKyXjDpSsA5V3WH7d2HZ1JS6JqsHKDeemGJsoAZ-w==>  


Let's Get Visible


Video metrics company Visible Measures has released VidWorks, which Adweek's Emma Bazilian says promises to unearth new video ad inventory in two ways. First, VidWorks ads can be integrated as stand-alone sponsored videos that get baked into publishers' preexisting video player lists; also VidWorks ads can be posted in nonvideo environments, essentially creating new video ad. "Instead of a black box where the right ad gets placed at the right time but you don't know why, publishers are able to see all of the data that we see and all of the decisions that we're making when we deliver the analytics package," said Paul Botto, GM of Visible Measures' analytics.
Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w8tQbudJtq_kpmozK-new05J6iZ7sKBl_8leFns93XjoqVwNfTtFB8lrHpoJF3W2H3dZEtX0aQ7KkXLLv7r2Ppup5GpmWVl__ztMIELI1iJyk-GeKxEK09arHIQ8_hTOyxQtsg4J1cuO9CnitljgZvgClLbZ9wzhN9InMhcVG9me3B2zf7zrnFlDIr_E5s91Ac2JfljUOsirHjWlhVNu3pMzDus8Ygrt>  


European Feet


Tag manager BrightTag has acquired Scottish rival SiteTagger as part of a larger plan to expand its global footprint. The deal, the price of which was undisclosed, means that the "team supporting BrightTag overseas is currently 11 with plans to grow," according to a company spokesperson. Read the release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w8tQbudJtq_rfm20Qd5-5h98CPPun8mK5CKbrvA7qm5JzXByS6HKxle5LVv6FHUtHnd2ovEGWA0eewtZpam09YPsqRtFDP8dQA7rBOqd3gGyU7ckMPTAA-BPIoV8Fhkk3154Y3Wr-QqhylRIw0R8NnKKezuimXVI0bSRt3oS-Qk-yHlJRzfoKtO5CZei-b4l>  


Skippable Ads


Skippable video ads have made their way to Google's mobile YouTube property. Know as TruView ads, enagement is the goal as The Google Mobile Ads blog reports, "Advertisers only pay when someone chooses to watch the ad, so their budgets go toward the people most interested in what they have to say." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w8tQbudJtq8QUEYnlkg6YXypzKDdgwrOhzOt8gbSuawhATa8nIo5qv4wp0LbzYpvncHTRcxHSh4MhIykixEJRls1y4YncprSc8ik8i0dH5dBYyJtPxXJZCymr3SNEts1PPnAjWmTcFvEYkWni5lh9gNqd7sMJ4lIHPAzMJXEg69FNJR0p3FfK99BgdX7eI7JsiKFY4AoyWA=>  


New Display Findings


On his Screenwerk blog, Greg Sterling takes a look at a new study on local display advertising through PaperG. Sterling observes, "PaperG, JiWire, xAd and others have exposed data showing that ads with local content are more engaging and perceived to be more relevant than other categories of display ads. By contrast this study stands for the proposition that "local context" matters. That's a new finding." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w8tQbudJtq9dWSqcBoXWz-8ZeERNcTlA7agzcrWPz_Fy_AjjoAo4xl_tu9IFC_wEYaF28yHgnDwe2e2oqLJ0Xg2Xz8Yx5GJKzY22uYdM4zrXPykOZsqUnTp6Ek7ujeRFRGVlq-Hms_5jIaLrFluTKjdZmexX1SaEBmq5dAm0L5-PN42nGmIeM59X_KQW_2wclCUJf0rVDfVU3fN2YECknQ==>  


The Gender Gap


The New York Times says that Google is trying to use algos to figure out how to recruit, hire and retain female employees - a tech, industry-wide challenge. The NYT finds more women on the business side at Google, but not as many on the more technology-focused product side that CEO Larry Page is known for. An anonymous Google exec says, "I don't think there's a gender bias per se, but I think the c-suite at Google is going to belong to product owners, not business people. People witness it as a demotion of women. I don't view it as that. I view it as a demotion of business." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w8tQbudJtq_9ZPVn-QwAR0BnnRghnWfQyVIJiXZU_vvsca3_L1P4TOrcYZd55TFiDbsok8Ui9GdZb4l1H-1vEn592__uAhXgS_xKHPEN8v3FPKK_Qlsw7UI_eMIpoL9KbDQ5ytQRMAxslRqIZf9OdvE06rCNHDmNRTA1OjYZonsOHDI6LjzlQAye6__1fEOalBlDtfqfnHNZs8QvYwF0Xsi0c9nomxHi>  


Another Social Metric


Marketers complain that if only digital media had a single, standard measurement tool -- like that Nielsen GRP for TV! -- even greater spending would be gladly lavished on interactive advertising. But Adaptly CEO Nikhil Sethi suggests just the opposite -- at least for social media, where he believes a new metric needs to be developed for the social space. Writing in AdAge, Sethi says, "As consumers behave differently when using social platforms, it is not a question of whether we need new metrics or not, but assigning metrics to unique consumer behaviors across different social platforms." Read the rest. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w8tQbudJtq8rqjtNwVT__pnoWx0a_MYV-Bvv7odPMoqvvSoNSv1QPv38Mx_Nk2WdbbC3xZ41-EOrQiYFz2o360LaxAXan69LyODv4y7KFztAvfTuHnIGzVrxp-_50rDp5d3kzRFVP1FnB-RlSy8kGmetbC28z3wYlZf_EX8xwxo=>  


Permission Granted


The search giant has revamped its "OAuth2" authorization system that allows marketers to direct a user to a specially crafted Google URL. Once there, users can grant permissions to a company's software to make changes to their account. In other words, as long as a user is logged into their Google account, they don't have to go through the hassle of typing in another login/password or, worse, spell out a CAPTCHA, to access a company's site. Those barriers, while necessary for online safety, also give time-pressed users a chance to change their mind and go elsewhere. Read Google's blog post <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w8tQbudJtq9SKUYnLxNBiqrj48qNHQtUfmA4h0Tc-kQrgelKoBTIjhxBkfTo0uqtQzxuloz705YFIeE0CneIHDphNGobW70VdRAzso4TX9V8jgJHe7ips7a5H8t3UZ6qiLAcRdcaIJxrPbydKbSWLtktDoD2EIia4w0nPlqgppKf_kDUJR6mnQ==> . 


Mobile Ads Made Simple?


As mobile advertising zooms close to the $2 billion spending threshold, there's an opportunity to get things right that went wrong on the PC-based web. Things like creative ads that are targeted more precisely. Zephrin Lasker, CEO of lead gen/mobile ad platform operator Pontiflex, tells AllThingsD's Peter Kafka his company has the space's problems all figured out. ""Cost-per-click is fine for the web, but we feel 'cost-per-signup'" -- i.e., lead gen -- "is a much better fit for mobile." Google & The Agency


Google will work with agencies to sell its social media marketing platform services now available through its acquisition of Wildfire. That was the message of yesterday's press release as Google's Wildfire "selected Likeable as a preferred channel partner. Likeable <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=00155_WyJT1mrHdIx_U32wGnv-QPA79KaZ-c71xKNcgINOxRgco2njDH7BME93_65pj0jlLXIBQ5ux6874P1I47m7vEmvnYXAfDePuBLELt4ltJgaKeOuwtew==> , a full-service social media and word of mouth marketing firm, will now resell Wildfire's Social Marketing Suite to its brand clients". Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=00155_WyJT1mrGTB1HhVcNrqnKntniu10qXRysRxpdQDlGwc4VOQgEGxenaxmiF-KsauhBssCxKwlQPAImDIrnGNk7ThwYohMcUsfSHnOVyqvtUqyxqsXv4YlpxbOXSaQid5Rcl6oF7VzWiU4tudCfImsvJVZ3UyRLdQ0_LLGVkjisfAAHrrB1AXFcaG1e4TfYVo25qXwxvp27_DqnJgbUTMmQ5Vv0dMulWw0z4afYZmBo=> . It will be interesting to see if Google can "sell-up" its DoubleClick Marketing platform services with the relationships that Wildfire creates. Social is not just earned/owned, of course. It's plenty paid, too. 


Ad Tech Landscapes


comScore's Kirby Winfield had enough time on his hands to post a "CRO's View of the Ad Tech Landscape" on his personal blog. He writes, "I took a whack at distilling this into a CRO style view: there are really four major groups of prospects for an ad tech BD maven, with sub groups as noted." See if you agree <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=00155_WyJT1mrF6SKhfJs_B8edhjcokTU-uGA_SjpXXJuA29oUtUly2mt0ibr789CH2BsvWOTF3qc5nFIV2aXjf-npE39yQKm3ummKYEBjBaCFVM0xzHvTSq9ua4jcUIXvbqi5iGoSIs-RiQTsmtne4t2ZPgzVEdQLMGUzBgXU17GyCVhJFgdqSHnLllWO_1xW3> . 


The Ad Exchange


Google Ad Exchange product guru, Scott Spencer, returns to the Google blog stage as he introduces new ad exchange GUI improvements to publishers on the DoubleClick Publishers blog.  DFP users enjoy ad unit level category blocking versus the old, less specific account level category blocking says Spencer. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=00155_WyJT1mrEmbMYdYWjWtczvA3F0ROU1cJANY26drwI9HOjMthuIetAt2ykTCitg8VLkD_eV6FLMNqWjr4g9aJmA_82Ex_JPA4gr3psqM-cQDvfwWdpaE__5gMeTbn68sKp_XUdF7XGtK3_SgKvtCO0BCBXizKSstY8maI4j6ub9uDukizI-g7sHOrtpjg1ChZzmOn-LO94ge3xxAsgm7Q==>  Feels so good. Compared to all of the fireworks out of Facebook and its ad strategy, it's been a relatively quiet, ad summer for Google. Is the giant sleeping or ready to pounce? Likely the latter. Need more DFP talk - read more on AdMonsters <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=00155_WyJT1mrHOSkLB9MPj0Jz3AO66svKJwEqplaINQq9cZ2laQjuFHuewmSubLulBV5lAn7n6uBw2EtU8YTBganBkezIvI0TfutX2y78j_l9z0PoVGTTc0FEX9124AqS4F68F7riq8CyQVRRilOFLb-wfXWf-272o5fZexIngVNv9kVNvnlAxQwIubeyTaMUi>  from Google's Sean Harvey about "Teams." 


Diller's TurnAbout


Barry Diller is making a $300 million bid for the NYTCo's guide site About.com and its related properties according to Reuters' Peter Lauria. That's above the $270 million we've heard <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=00155_WyJT1mrHMx9AuxdPvumQccBlv2kHlojeUcUMRXWRQ3UP7nM6hRT3-AALRXrXnpKnMy9GAFWeH1Y5X6rqV-0j-_W_t6k4NraUEHzMkYtNSrUgqc0XatD2it4vogLBquEJqMlrQwxFc7XYCxU3Jia2y56FJIZa-6U46mxo8vlYZTNJFKOLOW1gY0EuMPS-oQ9O73Q4cjX6XwFaxoAk-0w==>  being offered by Answers.com two weeks ago. Lauria writes, "IAC wants to combine About.com with Ask.com, which has undergone a strategy shift over the last two years from generic search engine to a question-and-answer style service. The idea would be to leverage the content served up on About.com to answer questions users pose on Ask.com." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=00155_WyJT1mrH5s4J2aOkfuOa8K9lGamNCoSteyzxmG1srDTWKPQzp0RrzLcp_P5XRkFawvOEe_M7gpPxkzWub-qnY5esGtwt-djISb4Erm2Bfgsu_Gq0yD08tpUTwph9QLCPtD5yplv-AxfSfVnkWjNYWPZYWcrW0-v1N_rNEm_AvtgDKyX1SkJ_MnPTYXp3EfluwEREnNKY=> . 


Social Ads Marketer


Syncapse, which acquired Clickable last June <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=00155_WyJT1mrEq6cCBwqyeDQTzvmGS72U28gMrBFMBmZMZ0pG0gk2O4zJEflHmG9lm9OsTEekhNpg_6mInwb9dUS2hK_kmIW78RYpOCnJBVG3lvpAitsOFgcdvclneQzTGK_wbTLffoscUF16OFQGaLQ==> , says it has inked another deal with Reckitt Benckiser. According to the release, Syncapse will "help interlock social media marketing programs [for RB] on Facebook, Twitter and Google+ across more than 20 brands including Clearasil, Durex and Lysol." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=00155_WyJT1mrFXdioKfTDsehXsg7HU0l3c7WmeB7WRsi6hTMgM0SRFN6IrmIlYJgsHNQCL3Hn3U8mAN1qCRxwehitOrIk9HR7cmcjzyRMGDXPoymmoJG3Lj3EaEoX7p-9NM6oEotl2FlubLmbMdovNslJvjmGzS5Psw1beKGS5U4ou5DvJDVGYIA1Njb61Q4H_Id0-hSqaTxWkFsnpydR0emNldxqBynT_0z9KOcFBX-H0oi-THW65O5eD4OJWrigL8-yTlImn7FYUs6tBEm2k6g==>  Syncapse wants to create a story, and likely an exit, similar to Buddy Media and Vitrue.

You Can BLiNQ


As previously scooped by TechCrunch,  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=00155_WyJT1mrF7JEc4sCJZ8M1qFrqmCizjeKT7A8d6K2JYr1fn_bDTgza3OByWFb5RhRgHBZvylpFzjDjBf2vaRSyH9Qgp0X7m-m67MHqMFgjzze6HQ2yCXRmaFYxbld5xmuML5Z6x3zJMFimYgkMryFV87nG4zTEKELj9E3oR2-MuvNE-WrFrOpLwfW2fGcHycpjfd8-2-2LAqx3Xh4DVPw==> Gannett has acquired Facebook marketing platform BLiNQ Media (last week's AdExchanger Q <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=00155_WyJT1mrHrk7hcCC8hv37INz2SmR9k6lY4sltxdWxJbE95sSB6_KcbbQ_oDp3N1ExXB6trjyQuvpgr7Oa79BQ4qUg97CaqtXpKMvm50OolC7dvrdRfcDNliLGxF5VQiTNaHWOnKGzln46Apjo3BgMp7nWwoadQbkDOUhFXqPoA8Rb34BjPTyNgaLoPA1Uf0MTm2N-lW8Q=> &A) for a rumored $60 million. According to the release, "BLiNQ will continue to operate its core business as part of Gannett's portfolio of brands, providing technology and media solutions for social advertising and engagement to agencies and brands. As part of Gannett's Digital Marketing Services organization, BLiNQ will help develop innovative social marketing solutions for businesses that want to reach local consumers." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=00155_WyJT1mrEAl7HJxBueSESzFaHqjy6Yn9COjq49qYjQfws_7YQPoMtUk28PMn7qapjCxoycoahxCavik0XzOytulb5NfBaloSBnnQghPibBofNwthYinXzpXCIVH0uCqiapIc9ftKjaDdeCun4oa_NpY7bnQsPGNlvcFKbnSnCdcAvt63SzWJpuaBwYJwUTI0nBGkax7npXaYfm2d56iLXg4DkGHy_nJvehDKToqDiIeQMw6CH8v_7sSqShkHXN>  


Condé Nast Takes Flite


The ad side of the business of magazine publishing remains squeezed, so perhaps this is a good time to reposition as a tech incubator. That's what Condé Nast appears to be doing by taking an 11 percent stake in cloud-based ad firm Flite <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=00155_WyJT1mrHZrO9WfJSdiNRQHoHVvpjtjQADMOGyMUQSWq3F4vYMOPEH2KyRRisruA1KucSttc48d7IPs3p5gbQXwNDxoEldwfwjmInJhPU=> . ""We're going to need a more scalable, more robust set of digital offerings that meet our consumers' and marketers' needs," said Robert Sauerberg to the NYT's Tanzina Vega. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=00155_WyJT1mrHo3LEITmvLHY8tHNwbm8v4qGa-9aR3Nebk4s0bUqlORgYq4Ze9B44f6K2bFskrHaSeOtQingU6i9LWYLTM3nGqyOm8xhefq_4pGwC49sCSGdnpQ5t7WkL57IGtmJ7ZpwB3C6zZlzNc1qax8ddUHTg2-safOuvNVCplAcOziM2TsLdMO53kNYiEOc5kT8c3e1vlc36COkvusSXXXUk2W7ftExo5rVQM00E=> . "We are actively, at Condé Nast, looking at a variety of targets to accomplish this strategy."

*	Will Consumers Manage Their Data? Enliken Makes The Case <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001336Ltgnbkr-XoYT3OzNleLTh96MM1SpAfGkGPfDQRKKPNuW2V9TS5EUaHQP5pKsZ2HRZhQ5bI2TftVnm9i1kMqM8hAUiq1e-rGiswN9Go6LLiX-M7c5-pHWXm6oewvB0pGbxShE1OA_Omouy-kCgOWno4BLWp0at0T8fBOrFSvDQg43kCM1hVYBMLqSkclMQS0lYHfP1x_h_9vCdsfO03NcSgM65qSCT>  "We think that as consumers gain control and they become more comfortable with the idea of sharing information with advertisers that they're going share more information. It's sort of like a cycle that feeds upon itself. As you feel control, as you feel empowered, you take a bigger part in the ecosystem and you start to feel more comfortable and you share more information..." (visit AdExchanger)

Hulu Ads, Direction


Big changes are coming to Hulu, and they're all starting at the top, beginning with the position of CEO Jason Kilar and the relationship to the streaming video site's big media backers, reports Variety's Andrew Wallenstein <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001336Ltgnbkr8OPHgWdTZLP_6YsdP9T1elnj2N6lyJCLwSakx3yS6T5iCCJvTGmZRB_-Mwc8Nz7XEM_J3Xcw9qkzQSviwxbgJxqxoFMeSPe4rHn5aVkUtJtXRQgATLIqgzgHUxEI5IZ3A=> . Citing a three-page memo about Hulu's business model that was dated in July, the document discusses whether or not Kilar will stay on after a big payday. Also, News Corp., which owns Fox Broadcasting, wants wants to see four ads per commercial pod on Hulu.com (instead of just one), and that's just for starters. 


Yahoo Exec Shakeout


Ad Age's Jason Del Rey reports that Yahoo! CRO (and former Admeld CEO) Michael Barrett is staying put even though other Yahoo! executives continue to depart in the wake of the hiring of new Yahoo! CEO Marissa Mayer. Del Rey writes, "Earlier today, Yahoo said in a statement that Mr. Barrett would be leading the North American sales staff on an interim basis following news that Wayne Powers, Yahoo's senior-VP of North American ad sales, was leaving to become president and group publisher at Parade Publications." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001336Ltgnbkr8hFv3dtI747KHN7pSYfG5XY_O9TjrC1ZPuP_ZPDMOBjxOIW5gCNAaLCNtnGWPuAi6SAC841Ws6ro05GQfsHmdMgb5ewZvkrXb4Y9WuZrJ3iArNJY7mLFp5SmSGpEe4xq1987EZgrQpp0Evp8YcWnFjRFOO6jxlMYxn7_hezVLqGKgRVJwqgdsD> . Yahoo!'s Barrett will be presenting at AdExchanger's Human Centered Automation Conference <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001336Ltgnbkr8VZ_QKv4Yn_gtYvngvxhifynwN6xyeOGsGj7QIsah7hgJ896wtcz0rkFu05L5tzGn0tgZWykB-Gu6IPluJl-xtoVLXoZvU9V3C2POe4Jc4uGpqxAlcah-FYTY20F2FwxM=>  on September 20. 


Video Ads' Emotional Missing Link


MediaMind's Boaz Ram writes in iMedia Connection that there's a world of difference between the kind of pricing that's commanded by TV and by most online video. It starts with the fact TV targets themes and online targets behaviors, "The Office viewers are there to laugh or cringe themselves to tears. NBA playoffs watchers are there to be exhilarated. Mad Men fans are immersed in a world that wears high heels and sips bourbon before 10 a.m... The demographic for all these shows may be right-on for a running shoe maker, but the emotional vibe? Might as well be three different planets." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001336Ltgnbkr8NMMxXpt198OZCdKDnajGJJMNfm28qq5qRqFc-fwiZjB8r_2OslL0mvyR6g4Nq1Mw0OAY2LzplEHkVr3BjFiyKhIgcS1qS2uP1RL2C2qcoyQVWeTlnBs5QbdjkLxX_IUn_Zy6-zgCY9A==>  


Facebook's Ad Pitch (Circa '04)


Facebook advertising has a long history that shows the company thinking carefully about its approach to brands and media buyers way before its IPO and the introduction of the Facebook Exchange marketplace. Digiday's Jack Marshall has found something of a Facebook artifact, a pitch deck from 2004, when the social network had a "the" attached to its name. See it now. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001336Ltgnbkr_W5E_rML0W8sSTmRpkuymYUy7GfbxakIGtHmhT84XSpheQwwi07A-uZeaolZRnQnBlUzDTvfS0juLEC1QPwFpwdLfd0kF0bZSWgT8_XYnqJcfV4yN05TnAuO1JkSsuT1FAdxk-YX4M8WANFo3-yRSWILqgUMhMt8QiiQnvSFM4xgQeq7ii7i-1>  


Cashing Pay Per Call


It's local listings plumbing or bust for Yext as the company announced the sale of its pay-per-call business to IAC for a rumored $30 million. Read more in Digital Media Wire <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001336Ltgnbkr_sfQV_m_LAR65BtoSyqjvmlOkzMe8b6ZQ_0ePM2LFhw4xRhMP5qHq8MvHQnicB3UX40f-fL4Qreu1PwEJ9HDL_YY5IQlB6ZCy5-fBkeh2qjqXlVWanFFPEFLALf_wIovzvCgzhIJtp7CzGCbw9kNe6E1bVPTvbHy-b7SkvgoOxw_68whz_TzZN-inxft6JlLHTidPAUnkVI34eK6mIQYYq> . In an interview with Bloomberg's Dierdre Bolton, CEO Howard Lerman confirmed the "ballpark" sales price and said that Felix (the pay-per-call biz) had represented 90% of Yext revenue last year. Now, it's all listings. See it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001336Ltgnbkr8f5Sfr4ftx8sz1YRClObmswj6W5pGcV0rYMaTv5bVur_TpampAQbLIQJoYn1vJf_fKn4e3BwhNERFeDzvpw29S6f0W_7bLVhBxjFoTt2YhWnEQA7CMgEkdHrUsK4Lg3YPo0JWAFJLVrLLwQ9oTkKa7oCU1CT4hhqTPnlGwOrcFo3AUTNsY8moAeAnJy7Agi0UHcD0O-6Cec6WNHH9g22P0>  And, read this May 2011 AdExchanger interview <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001336Ltgnbkr-R0q_D5dDJu-w88QD70zXMZYONDfoC4SMZeTaBLVBAQCgyWGuzkoWxvyye0eZWlNn2zMiRFT5mhOApTVr-rdA97kNqGEfhhcob6NU5NbVKyRCqnryiITI3VPjnWhYdTpSQCILFqAtfBnfdmcrQBbV_>  with Lerman when he discussed the listings business origins.

Challenging DNT


In a sharp rebuke of Microsoft's application of Do-Not-Track in its new Internet Explorer browser, Bizo CEO Russ Glass lays out his case on the Bizo blog. Glass sees harm for the consumer: "DNT is a blunt instrument that doesn't allow you or me to have choice over which of our preferred vendors are able to serve us offers we might actually find valuable. For example, if you were a frequent visitor to Amazon and they had a 50% deal on a product you loved, if DNT was turned on, you wouldn't receive that offer as you surfed the web. That's a bummer for everyone who wants privacy but also values a good experience online." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001336Ltgnbkr_rCFd9-T9JOt_LSkNC-wi36BjomQr0DQoYJOojr2rE5Iu1n1QiavWrW_-KkTQxr_4lpdY0POvDHrgszBu5j6I4YPmZWQ_QEnZpcCoOdPTNAD0eYcHpwuup5F-hlr7tLqQOpmvFINohRjfAiMksDxMSshBfW8Xa0meJSI8OHaCjTlvzmTqKR_fiwVuoRHVot9MDIzWhJ0uAYNz7TDYtlmjcUlswPVqNlQoZq1AGmgWAFVm7gburILPWajcCK8cT4x8hNuKwzJZJNxO7pO0jYLWMheNQEjtuDSE=> . 


Education Frontier


As web users get more and more used to free content -- and traditional media continues to see profits and paying audiences shrink -- there appears to be one digital area that people may be willing to pay for: education. Or, more specifically, something called "Techbooks," which the NYT's Brooks Barnes and Amy Chozick describe as digital manuals that include video, virtual labs, downloadable content. As novel as that sounds, even more interesting is the company's newest backer: cable network giant Discovery Communications. "Educational content is core to our DNA, and we're unencumbered - unlike traditional textbook publishers, we're not defending a dying business," said Discovery CEO David Zaslav. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001336Ltgnbkr_v-9TszXKtgxlZvNfbjpAWnWumQU_RjKXKT_rwKVuCUONkMNGd5niWOBjaNcuwPAqykWWF370uDuYMjuUDibZOPdoCKVukTP_uWCaVYXhO4-EK2XLIqjFIVXb5iAJhSZRRRGdx5Z3T9NEiiG6-cwiNOFzfoOaYnKgWRab0nsHls0OKfPItAHrYsUUxsyFKsNyTGfuhW1n8Sqb9j8Iy6N9gbTdvvKAy5oQ=>

Why? (visit AdExchanger)

There's been a lot of talk about channel integration in the RTB space, but marketers still have to face a lot of technological and workflow challenges. Fortunately, industry insiders openly acknowledge that online advertising lacks solid, intelligent attribution models so the market is at least moving past the 'turning a blind eye' stage...." (visit AdExchanger)

Taking Back The Data


Wired looks at the recently-announced Merchant Customer Exchange (see release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001QVqaYmAFZnbq4LazJ9OmX5ifptDbXO3pnka-n2WZsDx6HkqINm_0tPIN2N2CIHXb48KFEJTOaAKy3oPdsWtPXRdxYbAy-k8jysD0qC_58MrKvBHkkAgLajdDGcyH4dc77Rr3wnbk_vW0RgSrXOvEDCbWQlfOLfVWA59DReoz35fECSy03gVkxdbrf5iF5Rtg745ysjyiRbLrGLnVxPCHedfK8u5ELG25MLBuGTUmwyTB86SU2WsxlA==> ) that brings together major retailers to create a payment solution of their own and "hoovers" all that valuable customer payment data in the process. Wired's Marcus Wohlsen writes, "[The Merchant Customer Exchange] creates the curious scenario of chain stores taking on major credit card companies themselves, which joined with mobile carriers last week to announce their own committee to guide the future of the mobile payments industry. If retailers really do end up creating their own payment network, the strange new world of mobile payments starts to look a lot more like the past. Before all-purpose credit cards started to go mainstream in the 1960s, stores extended their own credit to customers. Credit cards came along as a way for retailers to outsource their lending operations." Retailers want to take back their first party data. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001QVqaYmAFZnZCpUM4_Hc5kW5g1yZKGF5u18_d_CCzmnANySAljWQi4la_mMlqkdBfGNNjxuJwGBt-O9AyYAnlA6YHI9jm1tus8p-NDCHJc9Gsdb4WxYuVpFiSehVQL8q_W7Z87-70zu98OFpzzs2K7RcLuupYGKbCvvcqGiTWrgGR4sKT4S2ph3kZgWhxPWGoZTPONNFgGQsNhVJPwbWZhg6mgmAd082tCQUGJVPgnPo=>  TrialPay's Alex Rampell says payment data is more valuable than payment fees on TechCrunch. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001QVqaYmAFZnZ6TUKqPbhGRHBYhCkWqYec_45DpElc3NMe-dZl-t5ocZb8c61efjt6CvAhm7_4hDxhNp39VAhmxRTOJeT8HN0ENeFYe9QzkrI3-Sye1hTiPHqCR1Vzlq8Jf8YQhpCrE2oKxSvxUM2_4BopHnarcSEurkY3TA43QTe_eZgIrVzJV4W64VQ1p9b11kjX4hFf5ss=>  


PLAs - Display for Ecommerce


The Rimm-Kaufmann blog takes a detailed look at client results using Google's new Product Listing Ads (PLAs!!) and away from the "previously free Google Product Search (GPS) listings." Results are a mixed bag in terms of overall traffic being driven -though the impact for Google's top line looks good: "The actual increase in paid clicks Google will see is probably closer to 2%. Still, that would translate to new annual revenues in the neighborhood of $500M to $1B in 2013, depending on whether the average cost-per-click rises for PLAs as more competition enters the market. To date, we have not seen any upward pressure on CPCs though. Surprisingly, CPCs for Product Listing Ads actually seem to be trending lower since the transition and they were already between 10-20% lower than CPCs for comparable text ads." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001QVqaYmAFZnazYRT3fmviE0fGQuko7Dfkw2NdmokkrRjPwngfYSGnS9MeOaSeSQuzFjhSsWDzo8YJZg3wXfV1eWYNxGMCeDtHTc4f5WIpWvEJXBjJu7ikAksAnyAwkZouWpOb96665LlSh77_4leNXtrucQDaVzrJ-OcSQMTMTFgApi8gPgWoV8i4l3RZN4araC3JCXVbP0I=>  


Icon Keepin' On


With the noise around Do-Not-Track, it's almost possible to forget the Digital Advertising Alliance is still pushing forward with ad tracking self-regulation. AdAge's Jason Del Rey interviews new DAA boss Lou Mastria about the behavioral ad icon and the future of the program. Mastria says, "One of the fundamental things not being talked about is that the icon program provides consumers with choice in real time, not some setting made on my browser two years ago that I've subsequently forgotten about." Read it.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001QVqaYmAFZnabMnRNTzhr1lasTVu6JsO7vPMjIA2sXApb785qfWav8pLOO-_orA4Fqp4Fuc1xyj3Ip_SJUylidC1qZRi_piQoI2UjPdJIo1lPi74B9SUhi07amPnV-6DWjlWOPqoHNby-3FfJAY36E5eTZBSo-pBoztgPqP4E8_r89T0ayqTI5NqPumJbbehKEvZret1V6mcn-iAXcsA56w==> 


Pricing In-App Ads


Need price benchmarks for in-app ads? MoPub has a report that may interest you. Among the findings: "Social networking demonstrates the most pointed growth in Auction Volume. Music and lifestyle apps also showed steady demand growth through Q2, and demonstrated eCPMs of 78 and 79 cents, respectively. Business apps yield the greatest eCPM at 84 cents." Download it  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001QVqaYmAFZnbX7TRuuufm4Xq0clYTrV3X3iZk2vxosVq67el3p2B8_4kOEsVyJW2NjVx682ZCrkmU19kROunBR_PLRRO2kEmDnrG36XM97yFMESY_VX1hPog0wk7qZ9MT> (pay with some PII). 


Politics = HD + Online


Former Peer39 CEO and MediaMind head sales exec Andy Ellenthal takes time to pen a piece on political ads and what appears to be MediaMind's integrated HD and online video ad business on iMedia Connection. He says, "Nothing could be more essential for political campaigns than the speed of the ad delivery. Candidate A says one thing, and candidate B responds. Advanced ad tech providers can guarantee delivery of political ad spots on TV within an hour, and a campaign can be online with that same video within hours of delivery of creative assets." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001QVqaYmAFZnbtbtVpom6eN_IRyXfKIA-eSy98DuTjIgT0932FqyWfHlUGwVgbNGFNkjGlzkDCfvyJ7D50DXcgAhQYOaGRnnpNmfBvf5dhFW679L1rW4Bfw2GgDUl53XMAnb-3raHKrhInS-9fsDqNBA==>

CRM Retargeting


On Business 2 Community, Eric Wittlake discusses CRM Retargeting. He explains the concept starting with display, "Advertising is targeted to individual people and may appear on a broad range of sites. But unlike traditional retargeting, where people are identified when they visit your site (and they immediately realize why they are being targeted), CRM retargeting identifies people based on an email address, even if they have never been to your site." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001QVqaYmAFZnakA-EIAd2PeAT_zVagYBXiPF2qxEl4eWcsUKdPPYLW7lNCoumoRQuLUd0Iq6kgJOC5f-BfzignBTu2BdEJeeFpWFFepq0665dSgWe6O8BQf6WBKPu7ZInzNbrTUvJV33kP2CjydBT8m_y_Wro4co0x78PuHIZl4fVSPz3pHBRzQ_W234AEPZrZKHdueIoXO518Cny1uCBa7NnhryhoGPPm>  Think Salesforce retargeting with email addresses. Will Buddy Media help here? 


Boardroom Lookie Lous


VC Mark Suster reviews the use of "board observers" in the startup board room... Suster warns the CEO who likes to add these lookie-lous, "Even though you might not be voting on anything in a given board meeting you might end up burning 45 minutes of a 3 hour meeting responding to comments that are on inconsequential topics from the 'over talker.' And the people driving your meeting off course are as likely to be your board observer as it is to be your legal board member." Suster seems to think  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001QVqaYmAFZnYQ5KSeeknFXh4ISghW84Pmn4TIEBN9w-R7acCSm7LjdwqWaK74Nsl9Ad7DmFEiJkyZngywyXJUdR5rTt7KnCsFqeQNWIVhKadrt1sr1bSoTk5eWgDVIt0TNDBvNJHCF1VRyo7O9bjdxatNkqHOt1SiOkc5vAaEhGIyqvc_EO9wJw5ybQW6wCmuWE7l5hQfKZfukhD832pNS-W3a7bQEAiBlsfnhmUncrM=> "silence is the golden observer". 


Admeld Appears


A rare post on the Admeld blog appeared late last week. Unsurprisingly, the Admeld unit has created a version of its ad ops plugin, Firemeld, for Google's Chrome browser. Google Admeld's Jared Magid explains, "We've continued to move Firemeld forward by adding deeper insights into how each ad is auctioned, the advertiser behind it, and more." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001QVqaYmAFZnb8G-Nt_k1xYWpaoBj7q1rRWlFULpfoafIDOXSDzutivoyq4-pT_uUl82OISYHAOZYy6KtW4Tw9Gs2u7o3VmhWsuay-opqE2AlBcTQCPeofL3oRXSAKE1Re6owDjJqKSaCkA_GGuGdkoPO8C4_t1IeSiEdrpxInpIg=>  Google acquired Admeld beginning June 2011 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001QVqaYmAFZnZIEbFTXiS2p0K-0HvntKXqzprBQM7E1RCK-ZdC2SXNS7xhQX8tORIND6IwkQE_4eWO464_6rKDOeP4NqWpyeB0q6LSx_eCF5oPgzukWK7c_nPKmipkzuaC2i-k9ZfQjulwBlYkjpg1vvMcSAprUMZU7ilzsnF9fMb4R9FK9M5h5cuRyBLRzZhQ>  - the transaction was U.S. gov't approved in December 2011 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001QVqaYmAFZnYUGyYqN9YC66jz8Wqic9NijwT321hY4B0Pf0WdNwwNB5vuscDJYkgj8-8kfKbeii9gwt881GtWCfETCCwH4s2cJAXK2fBPSsvkecO9O9nFAQJFjHOGTLO0HLhntDMsTk1Ln3og71e2-vsrmlPCYMX2u3s8WknzMb1_Is0W0-ucDl2l-DiAZoSbsv73ySN0g52T2c5U3BSNiYQZ1TA4aUJ-> .

Lijit Exchange


The promise of "brand safety" seems to be a big draw in exchange circles these days, so Federated Media's <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001hjtO7MOkAsgn1tTYalXxAAwXMmA0WaTP3LUSejXhkqYjEgpadof_OybHZN2ixVSBMfuAlk98CfjkDfh-0YAhJeDoKTuXj7jq_hqCOWTLl1nhwy4Yws9bq6xyaxalKo8Z>  supply side ad tech unit Lijit Networks <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001hjtO7MOkAsjwQPgoaHfo3jdf-_6amicB3Ahl9_Ru4okG8RielcoRo_5PqzxwTkTG-3KZzud4jOFE5Ij_K7kV7JhUPTM39mvNSaFS1OXj6wY=>  has introduced new inventory packaging capabilities on the Lijit Exchange to capitalize on the trend. In a "if you can't beat 'em," mode, Lijit is joining up with a number of partners who have already established themselves in the "brand safety" business. Lijit is working with semantic ad specialist Peer39 to provide page-level site categorization to media buyers as well as ad effectiveness providers AdSafe, Double Verify, Adometry, and MediaTrust. "Network hygiene is a top priority at Lijit and we are constantly looking for new, proactive measures to put in place on our exchange to ensure that we offer only the highest quality content on the independent web," said Tom Hart, Lijit's VP of advertising operations. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001hjtO7MOkAsj_bPKabh5rn4ed0Hppuch1pUJqs8Pm-kUSmF0vVElWXGn0oVk9uSamkK3pv8eIdCVsBHySVQDB7KR7D-v5FzsWjxTq5h_Cv-5LTaF1WRtdAhIQLihBIijF_4uZR5ELnb4EotXZ7KgoeYFmmYTwb9nY>  


E-Commerce Boom


The only reason offline commerce will continue to exist the next few years is for immediate needs (where are the bands-aids?) or as a showroom (read: Apple Store), says Chris Dixon. Given that the ranking of the leading e-commerce players hasn't changed in a decade, suggests the establishment is solid, while startups have been slow to recognize the power of e-commerce. "The key equation driving e-commerce is: profit = lifetime customer value minus customer acquisition costs," Dixon writes. "New marketing strategies ('content plus commerce,' social commerce, etc) lower acquisition costs enough to make startups competitive with incumbents." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001hjtO7MOkAsh4jxY94HsyDZ9OhTv0TgQSJi4vOpFbtEDXEz-kfFnawW5b2GubKTF1w8-xKFT-NxE2ddJ7hYtEbYBN25thNBKh1k48Li7wcC9pidwv4FBE6srI8psPRBFOH4WmRRSQnhVRtJqjc36qwEqTVIFiR1w_>  


Tapping Segments


A week after Nielsen rolled out new online audience segments for TV viewing (AdExchanger story <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001hjtO7MOkAsh0FlQK8BNi2zjDnC4eBoEnv45_9GI19EaRVdtFwLUZ9uFgEFXUTMSoQ4uA6vUB1XmgwgDA1toB8g4cqi1TO9_BMg2vfbZhkyxr7CdU6jyQoCQywUKxAK8MyDHP5xclMu6XJN8pDdYLIAVJKse5v1KEgk2-7sP-uGmtZB7ugLPq9qBydq4brIapUsDm7zQA0wozbCXJjIsURQ==> ) one of its launch partners is crowing about the possibilities. In a press release, Adapt.TV agency customer Mike Racic of UM says, "This new tool allows UM to easily find TV viewers and create custom segments based on a client's TV advertising buys. It also integrates with UM's planning and buying tool sets, specifically AMP, which is a tool we use that directly ties into Nielsen's cross-platform data." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001hjtO7MOkAshOsa2TqI39eet6kzVVmacYfKqKsgoVxrAVg04mnAfKkeD7EfR-eGmzV25tUC5TWvJ_QE5QBlFrQOn7xWkkj_teO7szbrTl_48o6Lu0ujOgo-cbo8DQmz2s6Xwl0olRnX_FFtgrLiSjg9zuz6RTo6j9mTj5S5kql1a2vKgsBv8dQQE5hYenGizS9HcgRtPrzvZwhoTqnfaPqq2f3ILShgtK8BLVHVexkKObnTBmplFFBQ==>  


Sourcing Demand


Daily deals platforms are still working out how to tap into merchant demand. Last week WSJ examined attrition (subscription) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001hjtO7MOkAsjUnVU4tm8FU6XbZhZJC5pMhME1mootLKJwb5gl37QCwRRSk-6BmA6VDOpOObmncpd_NvXV5SZTb3AzIRP-jPrbc23eCCC9gqqFswXjyuF2lUHbqHdoFWYRkupen4UujNsfRDZ3Ir4qOKVbRZtsMar8fwARkPNLEZQP3zfWcpP9zVSLi-C3LIY-QEyCDWqicptCKBHHuS1qDF2LSJMb6nIESGoSBrwmbBo=>  and disaffection within Groupon's sales force. Today we learn from Reuters' Alistair Barr that AmazonLocal is working with YP.com's local sales force to reach the SMBs that make the deals world go 'round. Local marketing expert Peter Krasilovsky says, "Sourcing local deals is the hardest part of the equation - actually calling local merchants and finding deals on a daily basis that are interesting enough for people to buy." Read it.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001hjtO7MOkAshptLdRFo8kvro1rO8M5_3AVDpetkvkwEJ_AKScWs4qkA1s3FToO4PB2ahaByQBXcE5UxKWaPodQJR36CTtjEEV56uFHZaD9cs3QjpzojLhtiAg7nH1XDXcCc8QKg7DG2duMJfhjMRF9_LgYIXuQtMlPWvgyomMi16Snzr9OR32tiiob0ZfyrL0> 


Shiny in UK


Shiny Ads has entered the UK market through a pair of partnerships. Gumtree and Unanimis will offer Shiny's self-serve platform to their ad customers. Read a press release.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001hjtO7MOkAsg1R6jh71I1C6-z6oAUMfINQsZsb9T7S1jlsuINtO-4WbGttIroZXkDqULO8vmWQAtUeNNfiTuQlINmZ3y-bXsZN4gOZlUVIW3nChU7lD9QmdhbBOiA7QDhQ0PJvbV1brfcdyJlmhaFk2nO07PmpqXfOu4s211qTPeddr4oUUfesZU1oKLDF6Tn4CgATFGpR90RywFeSrYUbnR2ATffWju7gx5P66J_mCE=> Shiny did a deal with PubMatic two weeks ago <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001hjtO7MOkAshNtfx5wcwmRKHXB4cNFGIdDS5klwJSOY1d5ysifaUrd646hT7yC43sFXHACTppybgOWdWrz85uaG7zaBHVCm9ShN79ZFT9e8r9CofMIRhIQIr4yXNqK_nFarpK5Wq6ucIwtke7z0za_mJHTtFQZySFB5qsmTA_i6M=> .
